overview_of_class:
The politics and poetics of Ethnography in Tacitus' Germania, F17

One of the first works composed by Tacitus, the Germania describes the land, origins, customs and practices of the Germanic tribes who, at the end of the 1st c. CE, still remained a substantially unconquered and "uncivilized" people and posed a real threat to the Roman Empire.
«Tacitus' Germania is a puzzling work: up to the present day it is highly unclear what the intention and scope are of antiquity's single surviving ethnographic monograph.» (K.A.E. Enenkel) The purpose of the course is twofold. First, by discussing literary topoi such as geographic determinism, indigenousness, military strength, barbaric Other, uncorrupted savagery and civilized decadence, we will try to insert the Germania into the broad tradition of ancient ethnographic writing which dates well back to Greek literature. Secondly, by placing the treatise in its proper political and military context, we will try to understand why the Roman historian might have wanted to write such a work. Selected passages from another monographic work by Tacitus, the Agricola, will help us look into the author's perspective on Rome's imperial destiny.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Course Prerequisites: Completion of Latin 201-3 (with a grade of C- or better) or a score of 5 on the AP Latin Exam. All freshmen who qualify for this class should contact the director of Latin instruction Francesca Tataranni (f-tataranni@northwestern.edu) before enrolling

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students are expected to strengthen their ability to read and understand Latin texts, as well as to discuss scholarship on the author or authors being read during the quarter.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Class participation; discussion; two 80-minute lectures weekly; readings

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Attendance; class participation; two midterm exams; homework; final paper; readings

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Tacitus, I, Agricola. Germania. Dialogue on Oratory, Loeb Classical Library; Revised edition 1914 -
ISBN-13: 978-0674990395

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: A good Latin dictionary. If buying new, recommended is An Elementary Latin Dictionary, by Charlton L. Lewis, Oxford University Press 1969 - ISBN-13: 978-0199102051
